summary: This is an urgent FBI email regarding a deconfliction request from FinCEN about releasing Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) related to Jeffrey Epstein in civil lawsuits against JP Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank. The FBI is asked to review names from investigation NY-3027571 to object to any disclosures before FinCEN responds to a judge.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Sex offender, subject of financial investigations
persons.context: The civil lawsuits against banks are based on their provision of financial services to him, and SARs related to his transactions are being sought for disclosure.

events.title: FBI FinCEN deconfliction request
events.description: FinCEN reaches out to the FBI to deconflict and review names of individuals and entities from investigation NY-3027571 before authorizing disclosure of SARs related to Epstein in civil litigation.

events.title: Epstein's arrest
events.description: Mentioned as a point in time after which some SARs were filed, though transactions occurred over a decade earlier.

locations: SDNY (Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: FinCEN is seeking FBI deconfliction to release SARs related to Jeffrey Epstein's financial transactions in civil lawsuits against JP Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank.
The civil lawsuits involve an unnamed Epstein victim (and a class 'Doe') suing the banks, and the U.S. Virgin Islands government separately suing JP Morgan.
FinCEN expects initial SAR access only for attorneys, but anticipates further disclosure to plaintiffs, witnesses, and between banks.
Many SARs refer to transactions over a decade old, but some reports were filed much later, after Epstein's arrest.
The presiding judge has indicated he may order disclosure if FinCEN does not authorize it, creating urgency for FBI review by COB 3/29/2023.
